resources.string: I am altering my course to Starboard.
I am altering my course to Port.
I am unsure of your intentions. Keep clear.
Be aware of my presence. I am moving.
Motor vessel underway in fog. Every 2 minutes.
One Long and Two Short Blasts
Not under command / Restricted mobility / Constrained by draught.
Vessel over 100m in length - at anchor.
One Short, One Long, and One Short Blast.
Vessel at anchor in restricted visibility, warning of collision.
One Long and Three Short Blasts
Vessel at anchor in restricted visibility, warning of collision.
Two Long and One Short Blast
I intend to overtake you on your Starboard side.
Two Long and Two Short Blasts
I intend to overtake you on your Port side.
One Long, One Short, One Long, One Short Blast
Tap the buoys to see their details!

Port lateral marks are always fully red in colour and are in a vertical cylindrical, or can shape. The navigational channel will be on the starboard side of these marks when heading in the direction of buoyage (towards the main harbour). Red Port marks, where numbered, will always be even numbers and may exhibit a red flashing light in varying sequences.

Starboard lateral marks are always fully green in colour and are in (or contain) a cone shape. The navigational channel will be on the port side of these marks when heading in the direction of buoyage (towards the main harbour). Green Starboard marks, where numbered, will always be odd numbers and may exhibit a green flashing light in varying sequences.

Special marks are used not for assisting navigation, but for indicating a danger or special area. These areas and points of interest can then be referred to on a nautical chart or Notice to Mariners. They can be in any standard buoy shape, but will be completely yellow and contain a yellow cross on top. Where lit, they produce a yellow flashing sequence which can be varied but will not match any other white flashing navigational mark.

North cardinal marks are used to advise mariners to remain North of the marks to remain in safe water. Dangers are to the south of these marks and can include shipwrecks or rocks. Where lit, it will flash a white light continuously quickly (Ql.Fl) or very quickly (V.Qk.Fl).

East cardinal marks are used to advise mariners to remain East of the marks to remain in safe water. Dangers are to the West of these marks and can include shipwrecks or rocks. Where lit, it will flash a white light continuously in a group of 3 flashes (as East can be seen as 03:00 on a clock face).

South cardinal marks are used to advise mariners to remain South of the marks to remain in safe water. Dangers are to the North of these marks and can include shipwrecks or rocks. Where lit, it will flash a white light continuously in a group of 6 flashes (as South can be seen as 06:00 on a clock face).

West cardinal marks are used to advise mariners to remain West of the marks to remain in safe water. Dangers are to the East of these marks and can include shipwrecks or rocks. Where lit, it will flash a white light continuously in a group of 9 flashes (as West can be seen as 09:00 on a clock face).

Isolated danger marks are usually placed directly over a shipwreck or other hazard to shipping. They have a black top and bottom, and a red horizontal stripe in the centre. They also have 2 black spheres on top. Where lit, they flash a white light in a group of 2 flashes.

Emergency wreck marks are placed over a new shipwreck or hazard to navigation. They are usually temporary marks until the shipwreck is cleared or other buoys are placed (such as Cardinal Marks or Isolated Danger Marks). They contain 4-8 vertical alternating blue and yellow stripes, and where lit, will display blue and yellow flashing lights which alternate every 0.5 seconds.

Preferred Channel to Port Marks work the same way as starboard lateral markers, as they show that the preferred channel is to the port of the mark. The difference is that there is also a channel to starboard of the mark which could be taken. Where lit, the marks flash with a green light in a 2+1 pattern.

Preferred Channel to Starboard Marks work the same way as port lateral markers, as they show that the preferred channel is to the starboard of the mark. The difference is that there is also a channel to port of the mark which could be taken. Where lit, the marks flash with a red light in a 2+1 pattern.

Safe Water Marks are often placed at the outer end of buoyage channels. They show that the area immediately surrounding them has no navigational buoys and is safe to freely navigate. They have vertical red and white stripes and where lit, flash a white light in a pattern of: One long flash every 10 seconds, Isophase (equal light to dark), Occulting (more light than dark), or morse code \'A\' (*-).
